Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploring Appropriate 3D Printing Paradigms in Special Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Three-dimensional (3D) printing is a promising technology that is gaining acceptance in mainstream education as a means to engage students in real world problem solving, design, and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) topics. This technology offers unique and exciting benefits in special education classrooms allowing students, instructors, and therapists to quickly design and produce customized physical objects such as tangible learning aids or custom assistive technology. For example, instructors can 3D print objects to visualize abstract scientific concepts, or create custom grips and handles to help students access classroom technology. This technology also offers the opportunity for individuals who cannot safely operate traditional manufacturing machines to build and customize physical objects. While there are many promising opportunities for this technology to impact special education, the needs and abilities of students with disabilities and their instructors have been largely ignored in the design of existing 3D modeling tools, machine operation, and instruction. Specifically, many of the existing tools have a steep learning curve, are not accessible, or are time consuming to use. In this project, the investigators will work closely with special education instructors to evaluate existing tools and develop new ones that serve the needs of this diverse and unique population.

Requirements analysis will be conducted using observations and interviews; evaluation of existing design tools; and the development and testing of new tools. Researchers will observe an established technology-rich classroom, provide technical support for 3D printing, and through these activities learn the unmet needs of people with disabilities and their instructors for 3D printing in an instructional setting. Through workshops and classes, the researchers will evaluate existing tools for 3D modeling, and provide support and training in these contexts, noting the content and kinds of training that are most needed and useful. The researchers will collaborate and co-design with stakeholders to design and test new 3D design tools, which will be iteratively developed and deployed in the field, and their adoption observed. Follow-up interviews and evaluations will measure how these new tools have addressed the challenges posed, and how they are perceived by the stakeholders. Potential metrics include accuracy of design contrasted with expectations and needs; satisfaction with 3D models and printed outcomes; time savings related to the design process; and actual and perceived benefits of printed artifacts. These steps will reveal what types of support are necessary for modeling and 3D design in these contexts, and afford a better understanding of how to provide a 3D printing instructional and design environment that is accessible by people with disabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While increasing diverse participation in science and engineering is a universal struggle, it is particularly important for students with disabilities, as they are underrepresented in these disciplines and rarely encouraged to pursue technical fields. The goal of this project is to understand how to integrate 3D printing into special education through designing inclusive education experiences and 3D printable assistive technologies.

Specific results from this research include:

  • Understanding challenges and opportunities to integrate 3D printing in special education
  • Curriculum design and recommendations for a post-secondary course on entrepreneurship and 3D printing tailored to students with and without intellectual disabilities
  • Demonstration of the feasibility of teaching young adults with intellectual disabilities how to perform 3D modeling design and 3D printer tasks.
  • Understanding impact of peer learning for students with and without intellectual disabilities collaborating on 3D printing and modeling assignments
  • Demonstration of ability to translate findings on peer-learning and teaching 3D printing to physical therapy graduate students.
  • Design and production of custom assistive technologies for older adults by physical therapists.
  • Collaborative design of a 3D printed physical prototyping platform called SenseBox with speech language therapists and music therapists for use in special education settings.

Intellectual Merit
This research resulted in 6 academic publications at highly competitive peer-reviewed conferences in Human-Computer Interaction, and 1 journal article. These publications were co-authored with 11 students (8 undergrad and 3 graduate).

Inclusive Technology Education
We studied the practices of teaching 3D printing in both mainstream and special education, formal and informal environments, and at many age and education levels. We applied these lessons into our own curriculum to teach 3D printing to college students with (and without) cognitive and Intellectual Disabilities on our campus. Over the course of teaching this class for three semesters, we identified many challenges with existing design tools and evaluated techniques to help our students master these skills.

This funding helped support Dr. Erin Buehler's PhD dissertation that explored accessible and inclusive technology education through the lens of 3D printing. Her dissertation contributes (1) a deep understanding of the role of technology in education for persons with disabilities, both as a subject and a medium of learning, and (2) recommendations and best practices for 3D printing with an emphasis on improving access to 3D printing and how this technology can benefit persons with disabilities.

By addressing the unique needs of individuals with diverse cognitive abilities, we can support the needs of a wider population interested in learning these technical skills including children, older adults, and professionals not in technical fields. We have begun to apply our findings in this unique educational space to the teaching practices and use of 3D printing in a graduate physical therapy program.

Developing 3D Printed Assistive Technologies
Our findings indicate that we cannot assume students will be motivated to create their own assistive technologies. Instead, creating custom assistive technologies must first be role modeled by accessibility experts such as instructors and therapists. We worked with physical therapists, occupational therapists, and speech language therapists to identify unique opportunities for 3D printing to create custom assistive technology solutions and designed functional prototypes with them. The process of designing these solutions revealed significant understanding in the gaps that must be addressed to train non-engineers with accessibility experience to create custom assistive technologies.  

Broader Impacts
In addition to the academic knowledge gained through this research, it provided meaningful teaching and learning opportunities for students and engaged local accessibility experts.

  • 14 students were involved in this research (11 undergraduate, 4 Masters, and 1 PhD student). This student group was very diverse and included 10 females and 8 underrepresented race / ethnic minorities in STEM.
  • 42 young adults (21 with intellectual disabilities, 21 without) learned 3D printing and modeling skills and the potential to apply them towards entrepreneurial activities.
  • 120 physical therapy graduate students learned how 3D printing could be used to produce assistive technologies.
  • We engaged 4 special education instructors and 11 therapists on the design and development of 3D printable assistive technologies.
  • We interviewed 8 special education instructors, 2 special education administrators, 3 assistive technology specialists, and 7 mainstream educators on current 3D printing practices and how best to integrate this technology into the classroom.

This research was conducted in collaboration with several local organizations who generously donated their time and resources including Kennedy Krieger Foundation, the UMBC Shriver Center, the Digital Harbor Foundation, and the University of Maryland Baltimore.

Findings from this research have been shared at many academic and non-academic events including the US Science and Engineering Festival, local and national MakerFaires, and STEM events at local museums and libraries.
